Question text: \text{Let }L ⊆ Σ* \text{be finite. Which of the following languages are semi-decidable?}

Question text: \text{Is there a regular language }L ∈ NP?
Explanation1: In fact, all regular languages are in NP.

Question text: \text{For the NP-complete problem SAT, which of the following variants of SAT are NP-complete, assuming} P \neq NP?
Explanation1: The formula is always satisfied if all variables are true.
Explanation2: One can write x ∧ y as ¬(¬x ∨ ¬y).
Answer3: \text{Each variable} x_{i} \text{occurs only once in F.}
Explanation3: As long as possible, replace ¬(x ∧ y) with ¬x ∨ ¬y, ¬(x ∨ y) with ¬x ∧ ¬y, and ¬¬x with x. Afterward, each variable is still used only once, and negations can only occur directly before variables. If ¬x is contained, set x to false, otherwise to true. This is always a satisfying assignment.

Question text: \text{Which of the following languages are decidable?}
\text{Which of the following statements are true?}
Answer1: \text{Let }L1 ⊆ Σ* \text{ be decidable, and }L2 ⊆ Σ* \text{ be undecidable. Then } L1 ∪ L2 \text{ is undecidable.}
Answer2: \text{ Let } L1, L2 ⊆ Σ* \text{ be decidable languages. Then }L1 ∖ L2 \text{ is decidable.}
Answer3: \text{ Let }L1 ⊆ Σ* \text{ be decidable, and }L2 ⊆ Σ* \text{ be semi-decidable. Then there exists a } w ∈ Σ^{*} \text{such that }M_{w} \text{ decides the language }L1 ∩ L2.

Question text: \text{Which of the following statements are true?}
Answer1: \text{ For every } v ∈ Σ^{*}, L_v := \{w ∈ Σ*: ww ∈ L(M_{v})\} \text{ is semi-decidable.}
Answer2: \text{ For every } v ∈ Σ^{*}, L_{v} := \{w ∈ Σ*: L(Mw) ≠ L(Mv)\} \text{ is semi-decidable.}
Explanation2: With L(Mv) = Σ*, these are the non-terminating TMs, see Corollary 5.51.
Answer3: \text{ For every } v ∈ Σ^{*}, L_{v} := {w ∈ Σ*: w ∉ L(Mv)} \text{ is semi-decidable. }

Question text: \text{For the NP-complete problem SAT, which of the following variants of SAT are NP-complete, assuming } P \neq NP?
Answer1: \text{The formula F is in conjunctive normal form, i.e., it has the form } F1 ∧ … ∧ Fm, \text{ where each Fi has the form } y_1 ∨ … ∨ y_i\text{ and }  y_1, …, y_i \text{ are literals.}
Answer2: \text{ The formula F contains each variable x_{i} at most 2022 times.}
Explanation2: For a variable x that occurs more frequently, every second occurrence is replaced by the new variable x', and we consider the new formula F ∧ (¬x ∨ x') ∧ (¬x' ∨ x). We repeat this until the condition is met.
Answer3: \text{The formula F is in disjunctive normal form, i.e., it has the form }F_1 ∨ … ∨ F_m,\text{ where each Fi has the form }y_1 ∧ … ∧ y_i \text{ and }y_1, …, y_i\text{ are literals.}
Explanation3: F is satisfiable if one of the Fi is. The latter can be easily verified.

Question text: \text{Let }\{M := {L ⊆ Σ^{*}: L ≤_{p} SAT\}\text{ be the set of languages that can be reduced to SAT in polynomial time. Which of the following statements are true?}
Answer2: If P \neq NP, \text{ then there exists a language } L ∈ M \text{ that cannot be decided by any Turing machine in polynomial time.}
Answer3: \text{ Every problem in M can be decided by a non-deterministic Turing machine in polynomial time. }
column13: All NP-complete problems are in M.

Question text: \text{Let } f: \Sigma^{*} \rightarrow \Sigma^{*} \text{ be a computable, partial function. The graph of  f  is the set} \{(w, f(w)) | w \in \Sigma^{*}, f(w) \neq \perp\}.
\text{Let } \Sigma := \{a, b\} \text{ and let L} \subseteq \Sigma^{*}. \text{Which of the following statements are true?}
Explanation1: This statement is not necessarily true.
Explanation2: If L^{a} \in NP \text{ and } L^{b} \in NP, \text{then} L \in NP.
Answer3: \text{ If } L \in NP, \text{ then } L^{a} \in NP.

Question text: \text{Let } \Sigma \text{ be an alphabet. Let } \mathcal{K} \text{ be the set of all context-free grammars with terminals from } \Sigma.\text{ Given a language }L \subseteq \Sigma^{*}, let \min(L)\text{ be the set of shortest words in L. Which of the following sets are decidable?}
\text{Let }A, B, C \text{be languages over the same alphabet} \Sigma.\text{Which of the following statements are true?}
Answer1: A \leq_{p} B \text{ if and only if }A \leq_{p} B.
Answer2: \text{ Let H be the (general) halting problem. If }A \in NP,\text{ then }A \leq_{p} H.
Explanation2: If A \in NP, then A \leq_{p} H.
Answer3: \text{A and B are decidable if and only if A \leq B and B \leq A.}
Explanation3: This statement is not necessarily true.

Question text: \text{Reminder: A family of languages is a set of sets. Choose all statements that apply. Note in particular that every decidable set is also semi-decidable.}
Answer1: \text{There is a countably infinite family of decidable languages } \{L_{i}\} _{i=1}^{\infty} \text{ over the same alphabet, such that } \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} L_{i} \text{is not semi-decidable.}
Answer2: \text{There is a countably infinite family of decidable languages } \{L_i\}_{i=1}^{\infty} \text{over the same alphabet, such that }\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} L_i \text{is undecidable.}
Answer3: \text{There is a countably infinite family of decidable languages } \{L_i\}_{i=1}^{\infty} \text{over the same alphabet, such that }\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} L_i \text{is decidable.}

Question text: \text{Which of the following problems are decidable?}
Answer1: \text{Given: A deterministic Turing machine  M  with input alphabet }\Sigma\text{ and  }n \in \mathbb{N} . \text{ Problem: Does  M  halt in } n \text{ steps for every arbitrary input } w \in \Sigma^{*} ?
Explanation1: Since only  n  characters can be read in  n  steps, only a finite number of words need to be checked.
Answer2: \text{ Given: A deterministic Turing machine  M . Problem: Does  M  visit the start state at least twice with empty input?}
Answer3: \text{ Given: A deterministic Turing machine  M  and } n \in \mathbb{N} . \text{ Problem: Is there a state such that  M  visits this state at least } n \text{ times with empty input? }
Explanation3: In  |Q|n + 1  steps,  M  either visits a state at least twice or halts.

Question text: \text{From which of the following statements would } P = NP \text{ follow?}
Answer1: \text{For at least one problem in NP, there exists a polynomial time-bounded algorithm.}
Explanation1: The problem would also need to be NP-complete.

Question text: \text{Let }\Sigma \text{ be an alphabet. Let }f: \mathcal{P}(\Sigma^{*}) \times \mathcal{P}(\Sigma^{*}) \rightarrow \mathcal{P}(\Sigma^{*}) \text{ be a function from pairs of languages to languages. Choose all statements that apply.}
Answer1: \text{Assume }f(A, \overline{B}) \text{ is semi-decidable for all semi-decidable languages }A, B. \text{ Then }f(\overline{A}, B) \text{ is also semi-decidable for all semi-decidable languages }A, B.
Answer2: \text{ Assume }f(A, B) \text{ is decidable for all semi-decidable languages A, B. Let A, B, C be semi-decidable. Then }f(A, f(B, C)) \text{ is decidable.}
Answer3: \text{ Assume }f(A, \overline{B}) \text{ is semi-decidable for all decidable languages }A, B. \text{ Then }f(\overline{A}, B) \text{ is also semi-decidable for all decidable languages }A, B.
